name: C
title: C quick reference cheat sheet that provides basic syntax and methods.

cards.title: Intro
cards.body: C quick reference cheat sheet that provides basic syntax and methods.

cards.title: Variables
Constants
cards.code:
const int minutesPerHour = 60;
const float PI = 3.14;

cards.body:
In `%-9d`, `d` means to output in `10` base, `9` means to occupy at least `9` characters width, and the width is not
enough to fill with spaces, `-` means left alignment
Another way to create a string
Creating String using character pointer (String Literals)

**NOTE**: String literals might be stored in read-only section of memory. Modifying a string literal invokes undefined
behavior. You can't modify it!
`C` **does not** have a String type, use `char` type and create an `array` of characters
Break out of the loop when `i` is equal to `4`
Example to skip the value of `4`

cards.title: Enumeration Enum
cards.code: enum week { Mon = 1, Tues, Wed, Thurs, Fri, Sat, Sun };

enum week a, b, c;
enum week { Mon = 1, Tues, Wed, Thurs, Fri, Sat, Sun } a, b, c;

cards.body: With an enumeration variable, you can assign the value in the list to it

cards.title: memory address
cards.body: When a variable is created, it is assigned a memory address
To access it, use the reference operator (`&`)

| Operator | Name      | Example |
| -------- | --------- | ------- |
| `+`      | Add       | `x + y` |
| `-`      | Subtract  | `x - y` |
| `*`      | Multiply  | `x * y` |
| `/`      | Divide    | `x / y` |
| `%`      | Modulo    | `x % y` |
| `++`     | Increment | `++x`   |
| `--`     | Decrement | `--x`   |

| Symbol | Name                     | Example  |
| ------ | ------------------------ | -------- |
| `==`   | equals                   | x `==` y |
| `!=`   | not equal to             | x `!=` y |
| `>`    | greater than             | x `>` y  |
| `<`    | less than                | x `<` y  |
| `>=`   | greater than or equal to | x `>=` y |
| `<=`   | less than or equal to    | x `<=` y |
Comparison operators are used to compare two values

cards.title: Logical Operators
cards.body: | Symbol | Name | Description | Example | | ----------------- | ------------- | --------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------- | | `&&` | `and` logical | returns true if both statements are true | `x < 5 && x < 10` | | \|\| | `or` logical | returns true if one of the statements is true | x < 5 \|\| x < 4 | | `!` | `not` logical | Invert result, return false if true | `!(x < 5 && x < 10)` |

| Data Type | Description                          |
| :-------- | :----------------------------------- |
| `char`    | character type                       |
| `short`   | short integer                        |
| `int`     | integer type                         |
| `long`    | long integer                         |
| `float`   | single-precision floating-point type |
| `double`  | double-precision floating-point type |
| `void`    | no type                              |

cards.title: Basic format specifiers
cards.body:
| Format Specifier | Data Type                                             |
| ---------------- | :---------------------------------------------------- |
| `%d` or `%i`     | `int` integer                                         |
| `%f`             | `float` single-precision decimal type                 |
| `%lf`            | `double` high precision floating point data or number |
| `%c`             | `char` character                                      |
| `%s`             | for `strings` strings                                 |

cards.title: Preprocessor Directives
cards.body:
| Directive  | Description                                                          |
| ---------- | :------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `#define`  | define a macro                                                       |
| `#include` | include a source code file                                           |
| `#undef`   | undefined macro                                                      |
| `#ifdef`   | Returns true if the macro is defined                                 |
| `#ifndef`  | Returns true if the macro is not defined                             |
| `#if`      | Compile the following code if the given condition is true            |
| `#else`    | Alternative to `#if`                                                 |
| `#elif`    | If the `#if` condition is false, the current condition is `true`     |
| `#endif`   | End a `#if...#else` conditional compilation block                    |
| `#error`   | Print an error message when standard error is encountered            |
| `#pragma`  | Issue special commands to the compiler using the standardized method |
`ANSI C` defines a number of macros that you can use, but you cannot directly modify these predefined macros

cards.title: Macro continuation operator (\\)
cards.body: A macro is usually written on a single line.
If the macro is too long to fit on a single line, use the macro continuation operator `\`
When the above code is compiled and executed, it produces the following result:

cards.code: Carole and Debra: We love you!

cards.body: When you need to convert a macro parameter to a string constant, use the string constant operator `#`

cards.title: Parameterized macros

cards.body: The macro rewrites the above code as follows:
No spaces are allowed between the macro name and the opening parenthesis
The function consists of two parts

• `Declaration` declares the function name, return type and parameters _(if any)_
• `Definition` function body _(code to execute)_

• `abs(x)` absolute value
• `acos(x)` arc cosine value
• `asin(x)` arc sine
• `atan(x)` arc tangent
• `cbrt(x)` cube root
• `cos(x)` cosine
• the value of `exp(x)` Ex
• `sin(x)` the sine of x
• tangent of `tan(x)` angle

cards.title: Create structure
cards.code:
struct MyStructure { // structure declaration
  int myNum; // member (int variable)
  char myLetter; // member (char variable)
}; // end the structure with a semicolon

cards.body: Assigning values to strings using the `strcpy` function

cards.title: Accessing structure members
File processing function
cards.body:
| Function    | Description                                       |
| ----------- | :------------------------------------------------ |
| `fopen()`   | `open` a new or existing file                     |
| `fprintf()` | write data to `file`                              |
| `fscanf()`  | `read` data from a file                           |
| `fputc()`   | write a character to `file`                       |
| `fgetc()`   | `read` a character from a file                    |
| `fclose()`  | `close` the file                                  |
| `fseek()`   | set the file pointer to `the given position`      |
| `fputw()`   | Write an integer `to` a file                      |
| `fgetw()`   | `read` an integer from a file                     |
| `ftell()`   | returns the current `position`                    |
| `rewind()`  | set the file pointer to the beginning of the file |
There are many functions in the C library to `open`/`read`/`write`/`search` and `close` files

cards.title: Open mode parameter
cards.body:
| Mode | Description | | ----- | :---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `r` | Open a text file in `read` mode, allowing the file to be read | | `w` | Open a text file in `write` mode, allowing writing to the file | | `a` | Open a text file in `append` mode
If the file does not exist, a new one will be created | | `r+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `w+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `a+` | Open a text file in `read-write` mode, allowing reading and writing of the file | | `rb` | Open a binary file in `read` mode | | `wb` | Open binary file in `write` mode | | `ab` | Open a binary file in `append` mode | | `rb+` | open binary file in `read-write` mode | | `wb+` | Open binary file in `read-write` mode | | `ab+` | open binary file in `read-write` mode |
Set the file pointer to the given position
rewind(fp); // move the file pointer to the beginning of the file
